Buttons.title: Buttons
Buttons.description: Buttons are one of the most recognized elements of web design. Sagefy provides buttons in a variety of styles. The modifiers are based on role, not appearance. In most places, where there are multiple buttons, one and only one button should be emphasized.
Buttons.example:
• Navigation, Next
  • Success, Accept
  • Error, Delete
  • Escape, Previous, Back, Information

Colors.title: Colors
Colors.description:
Four primary hues are used by Sagefy. All are generated via [huslp](http://www.boronine.com/husl/).

- **Base**. 80°, 50% saturation. Serves as the base hue. Also indicates warning.
- **Accent**. 240°, 100% saturation. Indicates a clickable element or navigation element. Also an accent color when no other is applicable.
- **Good**. 120°, 100% saturation. Useful for success and acceptance states.
- **Bad**. 0°, 100% saturation. Reserved for errors, danger, major issues, or to provide warmth.

**Lightness**. Any lightness values may be used. Sagefy recommends against values darker than 20%.
Colors.example: 20% 40% 60% 80% 90% 95% 97% 99%

Fonts.title: Fonts
Fonts.description:
Sagefy uses Palatino for titles and large copy. Sagefy uses Georgia for body copy. Sagefy uses DejaVu Sans Mono derivatives for monospaced.

- **Title**: "palatino linotype", palatino, palladio, "urw palladio l", "book antiqua", serif
- **Base**: georgia, serif
- **Monospace**: menlo, "dejavu sans mono", "bitstream vera sans mono", consolas, inconsolata, "lucida console", monaco, monospace

The classes `title-font`, `base-font` and `monospace` can be used to alter the typeface.

Forms.title: Forms
Forms.description: Forms are perhaps the most complicated part of any web design. The Sagefy style guide provides a usable, consistent, comprehensive approach to form elements. Forms typically have only a single column of fields. Most forms terminate with one, and only one, primary action button and several possible secondary actions. Most standard forms start with a title and short description of the form.
Forms.example:
A basic form

A description of a basic form.

Your name belongs in the box

Placeholders.title: Placeholders
Placeholders.description: Placeholders provide the user with an example of the what the field should contain. Typically, include _e.g._ at the beginning. Do not use placeholder in place of labels.

Text Inputs.title: Text Inputs
Text Inputs.description: Range elements do not use sliders. Instead, ranges are input as two text fields.
Text Inputs.example:
This is a success
This is an error

Textarea.title: Textarea
Textarea.description: Text areas are for larger text entry that a normal `input`.

Checkboxes and Radios.title: Checkboxes and Radios
Checkboxes and Radios.description: Checkboxes and radios receive some special styling in Chrome and Safari.

Field Labels.title: Field Labels
Field Labels.description: Every field that is not in a horizontal form has a label. The label clicks to focus on the related form element. Forms typically have labels above the field.

Optional and Required Fields.title: Optional and Required Fields
Optional and Required Fields.description: The label may contain a span with either optional or required as the class and copy to indicate the field is either required or optional. More useful for forms with more than three fields or several sections.

Fieldsets and Legends.title: Fieldsets and Legends
Fieldsets and Legends.description: Many users have difficult with forms with more than three fields. In such situations, it is useful to group the fields into fieldsets and legends to segment the field. These fieldsets can also be constructed as a step-by-step wizard.
Fieldsets and Legends.example:
Your name belongs in the box

Spam Fields

Select.title: Select
Select.description: The select component, more often used than the native select, uses checkboxes and radios and smartly updates based on the number of options

Form Description.title: Form Description
Form Description.description: A form may need an explanation as to why the data is required from the user.
Form Description.example:
A basic form

A description of a basic form.

Form Fields.title: Form Fields
Form Fields.description: Form fields are wrapped in a class of form-field and the type of the form field, such as form-field--text.

Field Descriptions.title: Field Descriptions
Field Descriptions.description: In the standard vertical layout, each form field may have a short description below the field. These descriptions are particularly useful when the user may not understand the expected input, or has reservations about why the field is necessary or beneficial. Fields typically have descriptions below the field.
Field Descriptions.example: We need a name to identify you to other users.

Grouped Inputs.title: Grouped Inputs
Grouped Inputs.description: Grouped inputs are useful for data entry where the data points are very closely related. Otherwise, prefer to stick with one column forms.

Horizontal Forms.title: Horizontal Forms
Horizontal Forms.description: Most of the time, the verical form is for the best. For small forms, it may be easier to lay them out horizontally. In this one case, it can be necessary to use placeholders as labels.

Disabled Form Fields.title: Disabled Form Fields
Disabled Form Fields.description: Disabling for elements causes them to lose opacity.

Form Feedback.title: Form Feedback
Form Feedback.description: Forms typically have validation messages to the right of the field.
Form Feedback.example: This is a success

Icons.title: Icons
Icons.description: Sagefy uses [FontAwesome](https://fortawesome.github.io/Font-Awesome/) where applicable. Use the `i` tag for icons, not italics. When presenting icons, label the icon. If you must choose between an icon and text, prefer text.

Images.title: Images
Images.description: Alt tags, title tags, and captions for images are recommended where possible. Images subscribe to the basic grid of `12px` as much as possible, more so on the width. Additionally, widths that match the grid system, `48n + 24(n-1)`, are preferable.

Image Captions.title: Image Captions
Image Captions.description: Images can be framed by wrapping them in a figure tag. Be sure to subtract 20px to account for padding incurred. The figcaption tag can be used inside of a figure tag to add a caption. This prodecure is useful but not limited to images.

Avatars.title: Avatars
Avatars.description: Avatars simply use the Gravatar system. Sizes match the image sizes stated above. Avatars are not captioned. TODO Add avatar example

Logos and Branding.title: Logos and Branding
Logos and Branding.description: The Sagefy logo is a mariner's astrolabe. It is presented on all pages, and clicking it either returns to a home page or presents an overlayed menu of options. The Sagefy name, when used independently or with the logo, is lowercase, normal weight Palatino in color #343115. It is not required to accompany the logo. When used in a sentence or title, Sagefy is capitalized.

Region Flags.title: Region Flags
Region Flags.description: Where applicable, we use this collection of flags for countries and regions. TODO Add Region Flags example

Metrics.title: Metrics
Metrics.description: Sagefy uses a larger-than-typical metric system. The rhythm is 24px both vertically and horizontally. The base font size is 16px with a line-height of 24px. Columns are 48px and gutters are 24px. Because of Sagefy's large metrics, a great deal of focus and minimalism is required. Different screen sizes alter the number of columns present. While Sagefy is not considered responsive web design, it does adjust to available width. Ideas are borrowed from Frameless Grid, Twitter Bootstrap, and Foundation.

Box Sizing.title: Box Sizing
Box Sizing.description: Sagefy uses the box sizing mode of border box. See the [Paul Irish article](http://www.paulirish.com/2012/box-sizing-border-box-ftw/).

Clearfix.title: Clearfix
Clearfix.description: The `clearfix` class clears any floats within the element so it doesn't impact neighboring elements.

Display Type Helpers.description: Helpers that can change the `display` property on arbitrary elements.

Body Layout.title: Body Layout
Body Layout.description: The `body` element will use up to 20 columns of width in rendering, but will adapt to the user's available screen real estate.

Columns.title: Columns
Columns.description:
Any element may be set to a specific number of columns, using the class `col-n`. Any element with set columns larger than the available screen will be reduced to the maximum width.

Borrows "magic" from [Bootstrap's grid system](http://www.helloerik.com/the-subtle-magic-behind-why-the-bootstrap-3-grid-works).

Lists.title: Lists
Lists.description:
Unordered lists follow standard conventions. Line items do not hold extra margins. Only root-level unordered lists have a bottom margin. Ordered lists follow the standard conventions as well.

Lists can be unstyled using the `unstyled` class. Margins still count on lower level lists.

Horizontal, or inline, lists are also supported. Often used as simple navigational menus. Subitems do not appear.

Lists with Thumbnails.title: Lists with Thumbnails
Lists with Thumbnails.description: A very common on the internet is a list featuring thumbnails. These lists are zebra-striped and can be marked up either as actual lists, or for convienence, tables. Lists with thumbnails use the with-thumbnails class.

Definition Lists.title: Definition Lists
Definition Lists.description: Definition lists are useful for glossaries, dictionaries, and outlines. The tags dl, dt, and dd are used together to form the definition list. Definition lists are also used for marking up metadata.
Definition Lists.example:
<dl>
    <dt>RSS</dt>
    <dd>An XML format for aggregating information from websites whose
    content is frequently updated.</dd>
    <dt>Weblog</dt>
    <dd>Contraction of the term "web log", a weblog is a
    website that is periodically updated, like a journal</dd>
</dl>

Vendor Mixins.title: Vendor Mixins
Vendor Mixins.description:
Whenever a wrapped property is called, all vendor prefixes are automatically added as well.

The following properties receive vendor mixins:

- border-radius
- transition
- box-sizing
- filter
- flex-flow
- justify-content
- flex-basis
- order
returns: Styling, for webkit, moz, ms, and o

Tables.title: Tables
Tables.description: Tables are zebra-striped, and common elements such as header and footer rows are available. Rows classes are available for each hue; as they only change hue, another indicator needs to be used to differentiate row types. Supplimental tags, such as `tbody` are recommended.
elements: table, caption, thead, tr, th, td, tfoot

Typography.title: Typography
Typography.description:
Sagefy strives to provide basic typographic support for all commonly used HTML5 elements.

For more on excellent web typography, check out [Practical Typography](http://practicaltypography.com/).

Links.title: Links
Links.description: Links are simply blue in color, and like other states, lighten on hover and focus, and darken on active (clicked) or selected. Icons can be optionally included in links. Links stay underlined to support the color. Visited links receive no extraordinary treatment.
Links.example:

Font Sizes.title: Font Sizes
Font Sizes.description:
Font sizes are fuzzified by names. Available sizes are:

- small
- normal
- accent
- large
- big
- epic
Font Sizes.example: I'm a huge font size I'm an outstanding font size I'm a small font I'm a blend-in font size I'm a lovely font size I'm a tiny font size

Headings, Subheadings, and Header Groups.title: Headings, Subheadings, and Header Groups
Headings, Subheadings, and Header Groups.description: All elements h1 through h6 are styled. Sub-headers use the class subheader when used directly below a higher order header. An hgroup collapses the margins between the headers. Optionally, elements can float along with the header. The most easy way to accomplish this is to wrap the header in an hgroup and add the class inline-block to the header tag.

Paragraphs.title: Paragraphs
Paragraphs.description: Paragraphs follow standard conventions. Paragraphs should be no longer than `col-10`.

Leading Paragraphs.title: Leading Paragraphs
Leading Paragraphs.description: Leading paragraphs, commonly used after the page title, emphasis a block of text. Often leading paragraphs are used to describe the page contents.
Leading Paragraphs.example: An example paragraph in the leading style.

Small, Strong, Emphasis, Deletion, Inser.title: Small, Strong, Emphasis, Deletion, Insertion, Mark, Subscript, Superscript, Abbreviations, and Code
Small, Strong, Emphasis, Deletion, Inser.description: All normal tag operations are supported and provide expected results. Note that b, s, and u tags are not supported, and i tags are reserved for icons, not italics. Other elements, such as var, samp, and kbd, are styled but non-effectively.
elements: small, strong, em, del, ins, mark, sub, sub, abbr, code

Quotes and Citations.title: Quotes and Citations
Quotes and Citations.description: The q and cite tags are used together to indicate a quote and a citation. All quotes are cited. No quote marks are included when using the q tag. In addition to inline quotations, blockquotes can be used to pull a quote out of inline copy. The q and cite tags are used inside the blockquote tag.
Quotes and Citations.example:
Prior knowledge has a large influence on student performance, explaining up to 81 percent of the variance in post-test scores. Dochy, Segers, and Buehl

Prior knowledge has a large influence on student performance, explaining up to 81 percent of the variance in post-test scores. Dochy, Segers, and Buehl

Horizontal Rules.title: Horizontal Rules
Horizontal Rules.description: Horizontal rules are avoided as Sagefy prefers whitespace over lines. Rules are useful in certain situations, however.

Definition.title: Definition
Definition.description: The dfn element can be used on the defining instance of a term. It is often used with a title attribute with a defintion of the term.
Definition.example: An example definition of <dfn data-title="The perception of fluctuations of air pressure.">sound</dfn>.

Time and Dates.title: Time and Dates
Time and Dates.description: The `time` tag is used to describe specific dates and times. It does not indicate durations. The `datetime` attribute is optional.

Addresses, Header, Footer, Aside, Sectio.title: Addresses, Header, Footer, Aside, Section, Article, Nav
Addresses, Header, Footer, Aside, Sectio.description: Addresses are commonly misunderstood elements. The address tag is used to indicate who to contact for a particular document. The tag is not used for arbitrary postal addresses and email address. Sagefy does not style the address tag. Other block tags such as header and footer are used for semantic representation, but receive no special styling.
elements: address, header, footer, aside, section, article, nav

Programming Code and Preformatted Elemen.title: Programming Code and Preformatted Elements
Programming Code and Preformatted Elemen.description:
Preformatted element defaults to use monospaced fonts. Computer code is syntax highlighted based on language.

- [Highlight.js](http://highlightjs.org/)

Alerts & Errors.title: Alerts & Errors
Alerts & Errors.description: Systemic-alerts are often used when an error has occured. Alerts are fixed to the page until a user chooses to close them. Very serious alerts can force the user to reload the page. This situation calls for a modal.

Audio, Video, & Embedded Objects.title: Audio, Video, & Embedded Objects
Audio, Video, & Embedded Objects.description: Sagefy uses YouTube, Vimeo, Soundcloud, Slideshare, and third party resources to render media elements. These elements are embedded by a simple iframe tag, with no customization other than size.

Menu.title: Menu
Menu.description: Sagefy's most common navigational element is a simple menu. The user clicks on the Sagefy icon, and a pane of menu options provides the user with more functionality. This helps to prevent cognitive overload.
